audio_caption: The clip begins with a female news reporter speaking in a serious and informative tone, detailing a court order barring police action against Imran Khan. She mentions Khan's alleged failure to appear in court and a prior standoff. A male reporter then provides a report from outside Khan's residence. Underneath the spoken segments are muffled sounds that could be background noise.

The clip begins with a man speaking in a news report style, detailing the scene outside the residence of Imran Khan, leader of Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf. He mentions that Khan has been based there since an assassination attempt and has asked supporters to gather. The speaker notes people wielding sticks are preparing for police action. Throughout the audio, there are sounds of a crowd in the background, suggesting a busy and potentially tense atmosphere.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker delivering news-style commentary. He mentions that "police of course has been told by Lahore High Court" and discusses actions taken regarding Imran Khan, stating that he will "not be allowed to hold a rally" at a monument. His tone is informative and matter-of-fact. This is followed by background sounds that suggest a possible outdoor environment, including traffic noise. The speaker continues, stating that Imran Khan "would need prior permission" for the rally.

The clip begins with a male speaker reporting on Imran Khan's likely appearance before the court in Islamabad, mentioning the issuance of arrest warrants in the Toshakhana case, and a party leaders' meeting at Zaman Park. He conveys hope for a resolution of the issue soon. A distinct transition occurs with a sign off, "Kamal Hyder, Al Jazeera, Lahore." This transition is followed by a second male speaker saying "and for more."
The clip starts with a female speaker announcing that Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan is joining them live from Lahore and thanking him for his time, delivered in a formal tone.

The audio begins with a female speaker questioning someone about recent events, including a police and paramilitary presence around their house and a postponed arrest. She asks if the person will appear in court and cooperate with the police. The audio concludes with the sound of unintelligible speech.

A male speaker begins by clarifying he is on the court on the 18th, giving background to the viewers. He mentions having bail until the 18th when his court appearance was scheduled, but the police turned up four days earlier, which he asserts was unlawful because he had protective bail. He recounts a massive force, never seen before, of thousands of policemen and rangers attempting to attack his house and arrest him. He then states that his lawyer gave the police an assurance that he would attend court. He explains that the police's purpose was supposedly to take him to court on the 18th. However, he gave them an assurance and states that once such assurance is given, the law dictates the police shouldn't arrest him.

The clip begins with a male speaker commenting on an escalating situation, describing tear gas, water cannons, pellets, and bullets fired, stating "It's never happened in Pakistan before." A woman's voice speaks briefly, then the man continues expressing his belief regarding the reasons behind these events.

The clip begins with a female speaker addressing someone, mentioning that authorities are saying "they've had to send so many police officers and even the paramilitary". She poses a question about the charge that the individual is evading arrest and about buying and selling state gifts without declaring profits. The individual remains silent.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker emphasizing "Firstly," indicating the start of a point or argument. He mentions that he faces 85 cases and six more have been added. His tone is serious as he explains that "every other day" there's "some sort of case" requiring a court appearance. He emphasizes that everything he has done is "lawful".

A male speaker starts by explaining that he could not attend a court due to bomb attacks and lack of security, judges and lawyers having been killed. He says his security team advised against attending, and they requested a shift to another court, which was refused. The speaker mentions an arrest warrant given despite a protective bail. He states that the police came, indicating that the intention is to put him in jail rather than uphold the law.

A male speaker questions why his supporters are resisting something, citing custodial torture in Pakistan. He details how his senator and chief of staff were tortured in custody, and a worker was recently killed and thrown on the ground, leaving people petrified. He concludes by asserting that the intention is not about law.

The audio clip features a male speaker expressing concern about potential imprisonment, custodial torture, and recovery from bullet wounds received in an assassination attempt. He suspects the same people trying to imprison him are responsible for the attempt on his life, speaking with a serious and worried tone. Following this, a female speaker identifies the previous statement as an "allegation".

The audio clip begins with a female speaker referencing that people are "petrified", and noting that people are being asked to "come out and fight". She voices concern about the potential for violence, questioning whether the speaker is worried. A male speaker begins to respond to the question, starting to explain something. There are background sounds of a bustling outdoor environment.

A man is speaking in an impassioned tone, recounting how this isn't the first time he's been arrested, mentioning "in the past six months," how they "came to arrest me." He describes how they came on weekends with warrants, making it difficult for him to go to court, and that supporters surrounded his house, because people know he says that "the assassination attempt on me was made by these guys". He claims to have named them and warned everyone a month and a half before the attempt that people were going to try and kill him through a religious fundamentalist. He's lucky to be alive and the "same people are trying to arrest me on frivolous cases." The speaker states that the cases are frivolous allegations and that the court removes or dismisses the cases each time.

The audio clip begins with a female speaker discussing an upcoming court appearance and thanking "Imran Khan" for his time on "Al Jazeera." She ends by saying "We do appreciate it." A male voice then responds, "I can't hear." There is a brief pause before someone says "Hello."
